And then they would come roaring to the surface, their guts expanding as that pressure let up, ready to spew acid that could burn a man alive…

Supplication.flavor: A drunk engineer made her way down to our barracks, babbling about her work on the Provost. Talked about code written in languages she'd never seen. Functions that could command all in its presence to listen to its screeching lectures. “That's not fucking code in there,” she said between swigs of toilet ale. “That's primal. Laws of the universe shit. That machine may be closer to God than any of us ever will be.”

Holy Bond.flavor: Artillery slammed into our bunker and everything went white. Thought that was it. But for a second I saw—was it a bridge? A hand reaching for me? And then the smoke cleared. We were still standing, and an Akavish Provost lumbered above our unit. “YOUR TIME IS NOT UP!” it shrieked. “THE ONE ABOVE CALLS FOR YOUR BLADES!” The grunts around me cheered and charged. I just stood there… still feeling the brush of that outstretched hand on my palm.

Time Shift.flavor: I didn't see it happen often, but whatever force the Kriteria could tap into warped time itself. In those rare moments, this hulking machine carrying a god-like energy generator would burst across the land. Nothing was meant to move so fast—I worried it would be too useful, too efficient. That there would be a price to pay for warping time itself.

Pandemonium.flavor: Elohim made all kinds of sounds but I swear I heard them… purr with delight when a singularity core was near. You'd install one, and their spines arced and stretched as they sucked it into their system. A second later they'd fire a blast so far… jesus, you couldn't even hear the explosion. Just see the light shining in the distance. All you'd hear was that damn purring.
